scenes.summary: Late in the morning, Dorian wakes from a long sleep. His valet, Victor, enters silently with tea and a pile of letters—including one from Lord Henry—that suggest the routine of a fashionable young man’s life.

scenes.location: The Library (Breakfast Room) of Dorian’s Apartment
scenes.summary: Fresh from his bath and dressed in an elaborate dressing-gown, Dorian sits to enjoy a light French breakfast. As he observes his surroundings, his eye falls on the screen covering his portrait and he begins to wonder if something in the painting has changed, sparking an inner unease.

scenes.location: Private Sitting Area/Front of the Screen
scenes.summary: Troubled by the suggestion that his portrait may have altered, Dorian locks the doors to ensure his solitude. Gathering his courage, he pulls aside the screen and confirms that the painting now displays a sinister, altered expression, forcing him to confront his hidden guilt over past cruelties—especially towards Sibyl Vane.

In solitude and emotional turmoil, Dorian composes a passionate letter addressed to Sibyl Vane. His frantic self-reproach and the wild flow of his words convey both a desperate search for atonement and an awareness of his own moral degradation.

scenes.location: Dorian’s Room (immediately after the letter is written)
scenes.summary: A persistent knock leads to the entrance of Lord Henry. Once inside, Lord Henry’s conversation with Dorian takes a dramatic turn as he reveals the tragic news of Sibyl Vane’s death. The dialogue juxtaposes Dorian’s shock, despair, and conflicted feelings about his past actions with Lord Henry’s cool philosophical musings on love, cruelty, and the nature of art and life.

After Lord Henry departs, Dorian, alone with his thoughts, reopens the dialogue with his portrait. He fixes his gaze on the unchanged yet ominously altered painting, reflecting deeply on the symbolism of eternal youth, the burden of his sins, and the irreversible course his life has taken.

Concluding the chapter, Dorian transitions from his private introspection to the public stage. A short time later, he is seen at the opera where Lord Henry awaits him. This final scene marks the move from inner torment to the outward performance of life, as Dorian confronts his fate amidst society’s dazzling distractions.
